text: today on x cast as anti-government
forces claimed victory in benghazi
clashes break out around the libyan
capital of tripoli and journalists
struggled to get the story out to the
world the concern about entering Tripoli
is that these journalists could be used
as human shields on Thursday clashes
surrounded the Libyan capital of Tripoli
with the bloodiest fighting in suya 30
miles west of the capital Colonel
Qaddafi spoke to the people of Zoe ax
and a 30 minute rambling telephone
address on Libyan state television I
have high expectations that the people
of Zoe ax will stop fighting and protect
their children from those who mislead
them to fight it is the land of 1000
martyrs these young people do not
realize that they have been killing
because they are under the influence of
the drugs while battles rage around
Tripoli Libya second largest city
Benghazi remains under rebel control
this is David bossy reporting from
Benghazi Libya we arrived in the
Mediterranean port city the MP center of
the initial anti-government revolt to
find a place that is regaining a
relative sense of normalcy
we are going at the protesters have at
least for the moment taking control here
but demonstrations still continue one
takes place at a former courthouse near
the sea Libya just just one family all
of us one family children crowded around
abandoned tanks to show off and take
pictures elsewhere in the crowd songs
are being sung of national unity while
the pause was taken for evening prayers
all around the city you see volunteer
civilians in charge of directing traffic
and manning informal checkpoints some
even set up in a former internal
security services building whose
occupants were driven away by protesters
earlier in the week there they collected
weapons from citizens around Benghazi
who said they no longer needed guns to
protect themselves a number of men here
insisted on making a point for the world
to hear in the eyes of some people in
Benghazi the country is united under a
singular national identity while Qaddafi
may remain in power they say Benghazi
has set an example for the rest of Libya
videos on Thursday the Libyan government
extended a strange and remarkable offer
to some foreign journalists it said it
would take them in basically to Tripoli
and travel through the city to see
what's going on there Italy destiny back
to Olivia it's a small number of people
who died in Libya and it is what was
mentioned in yesterday's press
conference we challenge anyone who wants
to say that it's one more or one less
person who died apparently the Libyan
government thinks that journalists have
been exaggerating the conditions there
the violence there even though videos
from YouTube and other sources show
widespread clashes and violence and
fires and gun gunshots in the streets
the offer from the Libyan government
prompted the State Department to release
a very unusual statement in which it
warned foreign journalists they could be
in danger if they travel through Libya
without the help of Libyan government
the statement said that some Libyan
diplomats had told the United States
they viewed all the foreign journalists
in Libya that were not there with visas
as al-qaida collaborators and the State
Department said further be advised that
entering Libya to report on the events
unfolding there is additionally
hazardous it with the
government label e unauthorized media as
terrorist collaborators and claiming
they'll be arrested if caught now these
journalists are essentially entering the
country trying to from two directions
from Egypt in from Tunisia and they are
massing on the borders essentially as a
sort of Armada to try to show the world
was going on there NBC News told me
today that at times they're being
careful not to say the town or the city
